clusters.title: New details emerge about suspect in D.C. National Guard shooting
clusters.neutral_headline: National Guard Shooting in D.C. Involves Afghan Suspect

items.title: New details emerge about suspect in D.C. National Guard shooting
items.standfirst: Two members of the West Virginia National Guard were shot a few blocks from the White House, and a suspect identified as an Afghan national is in custody.
items.content: Two members of the West Virginia National Guard were shot a few blocks from the White House, and a suspect identified as an Afghan national is in custody.

items.title: Trump celebrating Thanksgiving at Mar-a-Lago
items.standfirst: On Wednesday night, two members of the National Guard were shot near the White House​.
items.content: On Wednesday night, two members of the National Guard were shot near the White House​.

items.title: National Guard shooting suspect worked with CIA in Afghanistan
items.standfirst: The suspect had been recruited to Unit 03 of the Kandahar Strike Force, a former military commander told the BBC, coming to the US after the withdrawal.
items.content: The suspect had been recruited to Unit 03 of the Kandahar Strike Force, a former military commander told the BBC, coming to the US after the withdrawal.

items.title: DC National Guard Shooting Victim Has Mortal Wound, Says Father
items.standfirst: Following the attack, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said that an additional 500 National Guard members would be deployed to D.C.
items.content: Following the attack, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said that an additional 500 National Guard members would be deployed to D.C.

items.title: National Guard shooting suspect served in CIA counterterrorism unit, group says
items.standfirst: Rahmanullah Lakanwal, the Afghan man who allegedly shot two National Guard members in Washington, D.C., had served in one of Afghanistan's elite counterterrorism units, according to a nonprofit run by people who served in Afghanistan.
items.content: Rahmanullah Lakanwal, the Afghan man who allegedly shot two National Guard members in Washington, D.C., had served in one of Afghanistan's elite counterterrorism units, according to a nonprofit run by people who served in Afghanistan.(Image credit: U.S. Attorney’s Office)

items.title: Latest news on Afghan suspect accused of ambushing 2 National Guard members in D.C.
items.standfirst: Officials announced that Rahmanullah Lakanwal, an Afghan national who entered the U.S. in 2021 and once worked with the U.S. government, including the CIA, is suspected of carrying out a "calculated attack" against two National Guard members in Washington, D.C., on Wednesday. CBS News' Nicole Sganga, Nancy Cordes and Sam Vinograd have more.
items.content: Officials announced that Rahmanullah Lakanwal, an Afghan national who entered the U.S. in 2021 and once worked with the U.S. government, including the CIA, is suspected of carrying out a "calculated attack" against two National Guard members in Washington, D.C., on Wednesday. CBS News' Nicole Sganga, Nancy Cordes and Sam Vinograd have more.

items.title: Trump reacts to National Guard shooting in D.C. as details emerge about Afghan suspect
items.standfirst: President Trump weighed in on the shooting in Washington, D.C., where two members of the National Guard were injured. The suspect, Rahmanullah Lakanwal, an Afghan national who entered the U.S. in 2021, previously worked with the U.S. government, including the CIA, CBS News has learned. Nancy Cordes and Sam Vinograd have more.
items.content: President Trump weighed in on the shooting in Washington, D.C., where two members of the National Guard were injured. The suspect, Rahmanullah Lakanwal, an Afghan national who entered the U.S. in 2021, previously worked with the U.S. government, including the CIA, CBS News has learned. Nancy Cordes and Sam Vinograd have more.

items.title: 2 National Guard members in critical condition after "ambush" attack linked to Afghan national
items.standfirst: Officials provided an update on the investigation into a shooting in Washington, D.C., where two National Guard members were allegedly targeted by 29-year-old Afghan national Rahmanullah Lakanwal. The suspect faces several charges of assault with intent to kill while armed. CBS News' Nicole Sganga reports.
items.content: Officials provided an update on the investigation into a shooting in Washington, D.C., where two National Guard members were allegedly targeted by 29-year-old Afghan national Rahmanullah Lakanwal. The suspect faces several charges of assault with intent to kill while armed. CBS News' Nicole Sganga reports.

items.title: What we do and don’t know about the shooting of 2 National Guard members in DC
items.standfirst: Officials have identified the suspect as a 29-year-old Afghan national who entered the U.S. in September 2021 and has been living in Washington state.
items.content: Officials have identified the suspect as a 29-year-old Afghan national who entered the U.S. in September 2021 and has been living in Washington state.

items.title: What were the Afghan "Zero Units" the D.C. shooting suspect reportedly worked for?
items.standfirst: The "Zero Units" were considered by the U.S. and its international partners to be among Afghanistan's most trusted domestic forces.
items.content: The "Zero Units" were considered by the U.S. and its international partners to be among Afghanistan's most trusted domestic forces.

items.title: Mayor: D.C. shooting suspect drove cross-country to "attack America"
items.standfirst: The suspect in Wednesday's attack on two National Guard members near the White House "drove across the country" to "attack America," D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser said Thursday. The big picture: Officials have yet to identify a motive that led the suspect to travel across the country to D.C. and carry…

items.title: D.C. National Guard shooting suspect worked with CIA in Afghanistan
items.standfirst: A 29-year-old Afghan national named Rahmanullah Lakanwal has been identified as the suspected shooter in the ambush that wounded two National Guard troops in D.C., officials say.

items.title: Suspect in Washington DC national guard shooting had ties to CIA, agency confirms
items.standfirst: Rahmanullah Lakanwal, 29, worked with agency-backed military units during US war in AfghanistanWashington DC national guard shooting: what we know so farThe suspected shooter of two national guard members in Washington DC on Wednesday worked with CIA-backed military units during the US war in Afghanistan, the agency has confirmed.The alleged gunman, identified as Rahmanullah Lakanwal, 29, came to the US in September 2021 under an Operation Allies Welcome program that gave some Afghans who had worked for the US government entry visas to the US. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.standfirst: Guard members Sarah Beckstrom and Andrew Wolfe were wounded in a shooting that the FBI is investigating as 'terrorism'.
items.content: Guard members Sarah Beckstrom and Andrew Wolfe were wounded in a shooting that the FBI is investigating as 'terrorism'.

items.title: D.C. National Guard shooting suspect will face assault with intent to kill charges, Pirro says
items.standfirst: Federal officials, including FBI Director Kash Patel and U.S. Attorney Jeanine Pirro, provided more details on the Washington, D.C., shooting, where two National Guard members were gravely injured and a suspect was detained.
items.content: Federal officials, including FBI Director Kash Patel and U.S. Attorney Jeanine Pirro, provided more details on the Washington, D.C., shooting, where two National Guard members were gravely injured and a suspect was detained.

items.title: Suspect in Washington DC shooting who 'worked with CIA in Afghanistan' pictured
items.standfirst: The suspect who opened fire on two National Guard soldiers just blocks from the White House is an Afghan national who worked with a CIA-backed unit in Afghanistan, according to officials.
items.content: The suspect who opened fire on two National Guard soldiers just blocks from the White House is an Afghan national who worked with a CIA-backed unit in Afghanistan, according to officials.

items.standfirst: Officials have identified the suspect as an Afghan national who entered the United States in September 2021, following the US withdrawal from Afghanistan.
items.content: Officials have identified the suspect as an Afghan national who entered the United States in September 2021, following the US withdrawal from Afghanistan.

items.title: Here's what we know about the shooting of 2 National Guard members in D.C.
items.standfirst: Two West Virginia National Guard members deployed to Washington, D.C., remain in critical condition after being shot while on patrol just blocks from the White House on Wednesday afternoon.
items.content: Two West Virginia National Guard members deployed to Washington, D.C., remain in critical condition after being shot while on patrol just blocks from the White House on Wednesday afternoon.(Image credit: Andrew Leyden)

items.title: US suspends immigration requests for Afghans after National Guard shooting
items.standfirst: The alleged gunman in the Washington shooting is an Afghan national who entered the US in September 2021.
items.content: The alleged gunman in the Washington shooting is an Afghan national who entered the US in September 2021.

items.title: Trump admin. pauses immigration applications from Afghans after National Guard shooting
items.standfirst: Federal immigration authorities said Wednesday they have paused processing requests from Afghan nationals, after a man from Afghanistan was identified as the suspect in the D.C. National Guard shooting.
items.content: Federal immigration authorities said Wednesday they have paused processing requests from Afghan nationals, after a man from Afghanistan was identified as the suspect in the D.C. National Guard shooting.

items.title: Trump admin. sending 500 more Guard troops to D.C. after shooting, Hegseth says
items.standfirst: The Trump administration plans to deploy another 500 members of the National Guard to the streets of Washington, D.C., Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced, hours after two service members were shot.
items.content: The Trump administration plans to deploy another 500 members of the National Guard to the streets of Washington, D.C., Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced, hours after two service members were shot.

items.title: Watch: How the shooting of two National Guard members unfolded
items.standfirst: The two soldiers are in critical condition after being attacked blocks from the White House in Washington DC.
items.content: The two soldiers are in critical condition after being attacked blocks from the White House in Washington DC.

ai_summary: Two National Guard members were shot near the White House in Washington, D.C. on Wednesday.
The suspect, Rahmanullah Lakanwal, is an Afghan national who entered the U.S. in 2021.
Lakanwal previously worked with the U.S. government, including the Central Intelligence Agency.
Officials described the attack as a "calculated attack" against the National Guard members.
President Trump commented on the shooting as details about the suspect emerged.

items.standfirst: The Wang Fuk Court fire killed more people than London's deadly Grenfell Tower fires in 2017. Lui Siu Wai/Xinhua via Getty Images The Wang Fuk Court fire has killed at least 75 people, with another 76 missing, Hong Kong officials said. The fire is under control, Hong Kong's chief executive John…

items.title: Hong Kong police say unsafe scaffolding and foam may have spread fire that killed at least 83
items.standfirst: Three construction employees arrested as firefighters battle to reach trapped people, with more than 250 still missingHong Kong fire – latest updatesHow the fire unfolded – visual guideHong Kong police have alleged unsafe scaffolding and foam materials used during maintenance work may have been behind the rapid spread of a devastating fire at a group of residential tower blocks that has killed at least 83 people and left more than 250 missing.Firefighters were still battling to reach people who could be trapped on the upper floors of the Wang Fuk Court housing complex on Thursday due to the intense heat and thick smoke generated by the fire. Late in the day, a survivor was rescued from a stairway on the 16th floor of one of the towers, the South China Morning Post reported. Continue reading...
items.content: Three construction employees arrested as firefighters battle to reach trapped people, with more than 250 still missingHong Kong fire – latest updatesHow the fire unfolded – visual guideHong Kong police have alleged unsafe scaffolding and foam materials used during maintenance work may have been behind the rapid spread of a devastating fire at a group of residential tower blocks that has killed at least 83 people and left more than 250 missing.Firefighters were still battling to reach people who could be trapped on the upper floors of the Wang Fuk Court housing complex on Thursday due to the intense heat and thick smoke generated by the fire. Late in the day, a survivor was rescued from a stairway on the 16th floor of one of the towers, the South China Morning Post reported. Continue reading...

items.title: Anger swelling in Hong Kong over deadliest fire in more than 70 years
items.standfirst: Some think leader John Lee’s focus on blaming bamboo scaffolding deflects from actual causeThe inferno that engulfed Wang Fuk Court residential compound in Hong Kong is still burning, but questions are already being asked about what the deadliest fire in more than 70 years means for Beijing’s grip on power in the city.The death toll from the blaze, which tore apart seven of the eight high-rise apartment buildings in Wang Fuk Court, a residential compound home to 4,800 people, is still rising. Hundreds of people are still missing. Continue reading...

items.title: ‘There should have been an alarm’: in air thick with acrid smoke, people in Hong Kong are reeling and angry
items.standfirst: As apartment complex still blazes more than 24 hours after fire began, police suspect cause is owing to ‘grossly negligent’ action How the Hong Kong fire unfolded – visual guideHong Kong fire – latest updatesMore than 24 hours after the first tower caught fire, the Hong Kong residential complex was still burning. Fire crews blasted water from cherrypickers at the mid-level floors, but above that, the fires were roaring out of reach.Wang Fuk Court, in the northern Hong Kong district of Tai Po, was home to about 4,800 people. The eight-tower complex had been under renovation for years, clad in bamboo scaffolding and mesh. Continue reading...
items.content: As apartment complex still blazes more than 24 hours after fire began, police suspect cause is owing to ‘grossly negligent’ action How the Hong Kong fire unfolded – visual guideHong Kong fire – latest updatesMore than 24 hours after the first tower caught fire, the Hong Kong residential complex was still burning. Fire crews blasted water from cherrypickers at the mid-level floors, but above that, the fires were roaring out of reach.Wang Fuk Court, in the northern Hong Kong district of Tai Po, was home to about 4,800 people. The eight-tower complex had been under renovation for years, clad in bamboo scaffolding and mesh. Continue reading...

items.content: At least 83 people have been killed, and police have made several arrests, after a huge fire engulfed a high-rise residential complex in Hong Kong.

items.title: Fire engulfs high-rise housing estate in Hong Kong, killing at least 44
items.standfirst: A major fire tore through multiple high-rise towers at a housing estate in Hong Kong on Wednesday, killing at least 36 people, officials said.
items.content: A major fire tore through multiple high-rise towers at a housing estate in Hong Kong on Wednesday, killing at least 36 people, officials said.

ai_summary: A fire in a Hong Kong high-rise has killed at least 83 people, with many injured.
Over 250 people are still missing after the fire engulfed multiple buildings.
Authorities have arrested three construction employees in connection with the fire.
The fire is reported to have spread rapidly due to unsafe scaffolding and foam.
The death toll exceeds that of the Grenfell Tower fire in London in 2017.

clusters.title: Pope Leo XIV encourages Turkey to be a force for stability and peace as he opens first foreign trip
clusters.neutral_headline: Pope Leo XIV Begins First Foreign Trip to Turkey and Lebanon

items.title: Pope Leo XIV encourages Turkey to be a force for stability and peace as he opens first foreign trip
Pope Leo warns of risk from ‘piecemeal’ world war in first overseas trip
items.standfirst: Leo welcomed by Recep Tayyip Erdoğan as he begins six-day itinerary that will also include visit to LebanonA new world war is being fought “piecemeal” and is endangering the future of humanity, Pope Leo has warned, as he arrived in Turkey for his first foreign trip since becoming head of the Catholic church.Speaking in Ankara, where he was welcomed on Thursday by the Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, Leo said the world was experiencing “a heightened level of conflict on the global level, fuelled by prevailing strategies of economic and military power”. Continue reading...
items.content: Leo welcomed by Recep Tayyip Erdoğan as he begins six-day itinerary that will also include visit to LebanonA new world war is being fought “piecemeal” and is endangering the future of humanity, Pope Leo has warned, as he arrived in Turkey for his first foreign trip since becoming head of the Catholic church.Speaking in Ankara, where he was welcomed on Thursday by the Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, Leo said the world was experiencing “a heightened level of conflict on the global level, fuelled by prevailing strategies of economic and military power”. Continue reading...

items.title: Pope Leo delivers message of peace and unity in Turkey
items.standfirst: “The future of humanity is at stake,” warned Pope Leo XIV during an address in Ankara, on the first leg of his trip to Turkey and Lebanon.
items.content: “The future of humanity is at stake,” warned Pope Leo XIV during an address in Ankara, on the first leg of his trip to Turkey and Lebanon.

items.content: The Pope makes his first foreign trip to Turkey and says a third world war is being "fought piecemeal".

items.title: The stakes of Pope Leo's trip to the Middle East
items.standfirst: Pope Leo XIV is visiting Turkey and Lebanon on his first foreign trip, marking the Council of Nicea anniversary and meeting religious leaders. The journey highlights interfaith dialogue and addresses ongoing political and regional tensions in the Middle East.
items.content: Pope Leo XIV is visiting Turkey and Lebanon on his first foreign trip, marking the Council of Nicea anniversary and meeting religious leaders. The journey highlights interfaith dialogue and addresses ongoing political and regional tensions in the Middle East.

items.title: Pope XIV arrives in Turkey to mark Council of Nicea's anniversary
items.standfirst: Pope Leo XIV makes the first foreign trip of his papacy to Turkey and Lebanon, continuing a journey originally planned by Pope Francis. On this day, he visits Iznik to mark the 1,700th anniversary of the Council of Nicea, meets bishops, priests, and pastoral workers amid deep religious and political tensions in the region. FRANCE 24's Jasper Mortimer has the details from Turkey.
items.content: Pope Leo XIV makes the first foreign trip of his papacy to Turkey and Lebanon, continuing a journey originally planned by Pope Francis. On this day, he visits Iznik to mark the 1,700th anniversary of the Council of Nicea, meets bishops, priests, and pastoral workers amid deep religious and political tensions in the region. FRANCE 24's Jasper Mortimer has the details from Turkey.

items.title: Pope Leo warns 'future of humanity is at stake' on his first foreign trip to Turkey
items.standfirst: Pope Leo XIV touched down in the conflict-ridden Middle East on the first international trip of his papacy.
items.content: Pope Leo XIV touched down in the conflict-ridden Middle East on the first international trip of his papacy.

items.title: Pope Leo arrives in Turkey for his first foreign visit with a message of peace
items.standfirst: Pope Leo has arrived in Turkey on his first foreign visit since his inauguration in May.
items.content: Pope Leo has arrived in Turkey on his first foreign visit since his inauguration in May.

ai_summary: Pope Leo XIV is on his first foreign trip since becoming head of the Catholic Church.
He is visiting Turkey and Lebanon, marking the Council of Nicea anniversary.
The Pope warned of a "piecemeal" world war endangering the future of humanity.
He met with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan in Ankara.
The trip highlights interfaith dialogue and addresses regional tensions.

clusters.title: Putin says US peace plan could form basis for end to Ukraine war – as it happened

items.title: Putin says US peace plan could form basis for end to Ukraine war – as it happened
items.standfirst: This live blog is now closed. You can read our latest reports here:Putin insists Ukraine has to surrender territory for any deal to be possibleFrance to introduce voluntary military service amid threat from RussiaMeanwhile, we are getting some new lines from Russia on what would and wouldn’t be acceptable to Moscow in a potential peace deal on Ukraine.Foreign ministry spokesperson Maria Zakharova said that Ukrainian membership of Nato would be unacceptable, as she blamed the alliance for trying to draw Ukraine into its structure and pose a threat against Russia, Reuters reported. Continue reading...
items.content: This live blog is now closed. You can read our latest reports here:Putin insists Ukraine has to surrender territory for any deal to be possibleFrance to introduce voluntary military service amid threat from RussiaMeanwhile, we are getting some new lines from Russia on what would and wouldn’t be acceptable to Moscow in a potential peace deal on Ukraine.Foreign ministry spokesperson Maria Zakharova said that Ukrainian membership of Nato would be unacceptable, as she blamed the alliance for trying to draw Ukraine into its structure and pose a threat against Russia, Reuters reported. Continue reading...

items.title: Putin insists Ukraine has to surrender territory for any deal to be possible
items.standfirst: Russian president says latest draft peace plan ‘can be basis for future agreements’ if Kyiv gives up unspecified areasVladimir Putin has said that the outline of a draft peace plan discussed by the US and Ukraine could serve as a basis for future negotiations to end the war – but insisted Ukraine would have to surrender territory for any deal to be possible.“In general, we agree that this can be the basis for future agreements,” Putin said, noting that the version of the plan discussed by Washington and Kyiv in Geneva had been shared with Moscow. Continue reading...
items.content: Russian president says latest draft peace plan ‘can be basis for future agreements’ if Kyiv gives up unspecified areasVladimir Putin has said that the outline of a draft peace plan discussed by the US and Ukraine could serve as a basis for future negotiations to end the war – but insisted Ukraine would have to surrender territory for any deal to be possible.“In general, we agree that this can be the basis for future agreements,” Putin said, noting that the version of the plan discussed by Washington and Kyiv in Geneva had been shared with Moscow. Continue reading...

items.content: The Russian president accuses Kyiv of wanting to fight "to the last Ukrainian" - which he says Russia is also "in principle" ready to do.

items.title: Putin ready for 'serious' peace talks and says U.S.-Ukraine draft could be basis for a deal
items.standfirst: Russia is ready for “serious” peace talks, Vladimir Putin said Thursday, adding that the draft of a plan discussed by the United States and Ukraine could form the basis of a future deal to end the conflict
items.content: Russia is ready for “serious” peace talks, Vladimir Putin said Thursday, adding that the draft of a plan discussed by the United States and Ukraine could form the basis of a future deal to end the conflict

ai_summary: Vladimir Putin stated a US-Ukraine peace plan could be a basis for talks.
Putin insisted Ukraine must surrender territory for any deal to be possible.
A 28-point outline of the plan was shared with Moscow, according to Putin.
US envoys are heading to Moscow for further discussions on the matter.
Putin accused Kyiv of wanting to fight "to the last Ukrainian".

items.title: Guinea-Bissau, a day after the military coup
items.standfirst: A day after the military seized power in Guinea-Bissau, General N’Tal was sworn in as interim president during a brief ceremony surrounded by heavily armed soldiers. Once considered a close ally of ousted President Umaro Sissoco Embaló, N’Tal now heads what the army describes as a new command, following Embaló’s arrest and detention.

items.title: Guinea-Bissau: General N'Tam named interim president after coup
items.standfirst: General N’Tam was sworn in as Guinea-Bissau’s interim president during a brief ceremony guarded by heavily armed soldiers, a day after the coup that ousted President Umaro Sissoco Embaló. N’Tal, believed to have been a close ally of Embaló, now leads what the military calls a new command, after the former president was arrested and detained. With institutions suspended and events unfolding rapidly following recent elections, the country is facing a highly unstable and fast-moving political situation, as FRANCE 24's Caitlin Kelly explains.

items.title: Government to ditch day-one unfair dismissal policy from workers’ rights bill
items.standfirst: Flagship Labour plan to be replaced with six-month threshold after Peter Kyle vows to not let businesses ‘lose’ under new lawThe government is to ditch its flagship policy from the workers’ rights bill, removing the right to protection from unfair dismissal from the first day of employment and replacing it with a six-month threshold.The move comes after the business secretary, Peter Kyle, told businesses at the CBI conference this week that he would listen to concerns about the effects of the law change on hiring. A trade union source told the Guardian: “They’ve capitulated and there may be more to come.” Continue reading...

items.title: Lebanon-Israel: One year into the fragile ceasefire
items.standfirst: A year ago, Israel and Lebanon agreed to a ceasefire after several weeks of intense fighting, triggered in part by the so-called 'pager attack' involving Hezbollah members. items.standfirst: Prime minister says deal ‘sets the state for an industrial transformation’, but project is likely to face wide oppositionMark Carney has agreed an energy deal with Alberta centred on plans for a new heavy oil pipeline reaching from the province’s oil sands to the Pacific coast, a politically volatile project that is expected to face stiff opposition.“It’s a great day for Alberta and a great day for Canada,” the prime minister said on Thursday as he met the Alberta premier, Danielle Smith. He said the agreement “sets the state for an industrial transformation” and involved not just a pipeline, but nuclear power and datacentres. “This is Canada working,” he said. Continue reading...
